abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Lahore Urban
            Development Project for Pakistan was satisfactory. The
            project achieved its principal objectives, its impact on
            institutional development has been substantial,
            sustainability is uncertain at this time, and both the Bank
            and Borrower performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can
            be learned from this project. First, the estimate of the
            time required for implementation was overly optimistic.
            Second, the difficult problems associated with land
            acquisition for the Gujjapura component, and to a lesser
            extent, the solid waste management component, were not fully
            appreciated at appraisal. Third, there is a need for a
            strategy for land acquisition as the lack of one caused
            major delays. Fourth, urban projects involving multi-agency
            execution should include a mechanism for integrated project
            monitoring, coordination, and evaluation. Fifth, the delays
            with Gujjapura contrasted sharply with the timely benefits
            provided under the Walled City upgrade. Future projects
            should concentrate on area upgrading rather than on sites
            and services. Lastly, the use of integrated area-based
            packages for basic service civil works contracts should be
            carefully reviewed in the context of locally available
            contractor expertise.
